name: impartible

Impartible land or other property cannot be divided, especially when it is passed from someone after they die to another person: impartible inheritance This system gave way to impartible inheritance, with one heir alone inheriting. Inheritance in Japan was usually regarded as impartible in that one heir inherited the position and responsibilities of the head.
More examplesFewer examplesThe second option, impartible inheritance, meant keeping all property in common and living under the same roof. Of all the Spanish regions, Catalonia practised the most impartible form of inheritance.
